title: Bahamas Threatened With Another Storm, Forecasters Warn
text:
A storm brewing near the Bahamas is threatening to drench the islands, including areas devastated by the deadly Hurricane Dorian less than two weeks ago.

A weather system located about 310 miles southeast of Freeport on Grand Bahama Island on Thursday afternoon was expected to become a tropical storm near the northwestern Bahamas, U.S. forecasters said. The Bahamas government issued a tropical storm warning for several islands, including the Abacos and Grand Bahama, which were hard hit by Dorian, forecasters said.

“The disturbance is expected to become a tropical storm and bring tropical storm-force winds to portions of the northwest Bahamas within 36 hours,” forecasters said.

That forecast was a major concern for officials in the Bahamas who are worried about the islands’ ability to withstand another battering, even if not hurricane-strength. “You’ve got to take it seriously,” said Duane Sands, minister of health in the Bahamas. “It also impacts the day-to-day reality of the people whose roofs have been blown off their homes. Now that they’ve been traumatized, this could be the straw that breaks the camel’s back.” Some 5,000 people had been evacuated because of Dorian as of Tuesday, according to the latest situation report from the Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency. Roughly 2,000 were staying in shelters, and an estimated 15,000 were in need of aid, it said. The death toll from Dorian stood at 50, though officials expect that number to rise significantly. Mr. Sands said he has seen lists of “many, many, many hundreds” of people reported missing. Confirming whether those people perished is a daunting task. Search teams are combing the rubble, but they must move slowly to avoid damaging any human remains, Mr. Sands said. The health minister said he fears many people were swept into the sea by massive storm surges and may never be found. “The ocean came in during the storm and then it receded, so you don’t know what happened to a number of people,” he said. “That their remains will definitely be on land may be a bit of a stretch.” Write to Erin Ailworth at Erin.Ailworth@wsj.com
